#   class ScalarDie(icepool.BaseDie):
View Source 
 12class ScalarDie(icepool.die.base.BaseDie):
 13    """ Univariate die.
 14    
 15    Outcomes are scalars and operations are performed directly on the outcomes.
 16    """
 17    
 18    def ndim(self):
 19        return 'scalar'
 20    
 21    def __init__(self, data):
 22        """ Constructor.
 23        
 24        Dice should not be constructed directly;
 25        instead, use one of the methods defined in `icepool.die.func` 
 26        (which are imported into the top-level `icepool` module).
 27        
 28        Args:
 29            data: A `Counts` mapping outcomes to weights.
 30        """
 31        self._data = data
 32    
 33    def _unary_op(self, op, *args, **kwargs):
 34        """ Returns a die representing the effect of performing the operation on the outcomes. """
 35        data = defaultdict(int)
 36        for outcome, weight in self.items():
 37            data[op(outcome, *args, **kwargs)] += weight
 38        return icepool.Die(data, ndim='scalar')
 39    
 40    def _binary_op(self, other, op, *args, **kwargs):
 41        """ Returns a die representing the effect of performing the operation on pairs of outcomes from the two dice. """
 42        data = defaultdict(int)
 43        for (outcome_self, weight_self), (outcome_other, weight_other) in itertools.product(self.items(), other.items()):
 44            data[op(outcome_self, outcome_other, *args, **kwargs)] += weight_self * weight_other
 45        return icepool.Die(data, ndim='scalar')
 46    
 47    def _wrap_unpack(self, func):
 48        return func
 49    
 50    # Special operators.
 51    
 52    def d(self, other, *, ndim=None):
 53        """ Roll the left die, then roll the right die that many times and sum the outcomes. 
 54        
 55        If an `int` is provided for the right side, it becomes a standard die with that many faces.
 56        Otherwise it is cast to a die.
 57        """
 58        if isinstance(other, int):
 59            other = icepool.standard(other)
 60        else:
 61            other = icepool.Die(other, ndim=ndim)
 62        
 63        data = defaultdict(int)
 64        
 65        max_abs_die_count = max(abs(self.min_outcome()), abs(self.max_outcome()))
 66        for die_count, die_count_weight in self.items():
 67            factor = other.denominator() ** (max_abs_die_count - abs(die_count))
 68            subresult = other.repeat_and_sum(die_count)
 69            for outcome, subresult_weight in subresult.items():
 70                data[outcome] += subresult_weight * die_count_weight * factor
 71            
 72        return icepool.Die(data, ndim=other.ndim())
 73    
 74    def __matmul__(self, other):
 75        """ Roll the left die, then roll the right die that many times and sum the outcomes. 
 76        
 77        Unlike other operators, this does not work for built-in types on the right side.
 78        For example, `1 @ 6` does not work, nor does `d(6) @ 6`. But `1 @ d(6)` works.
 79        
 80        This is because all other operators convert their right side to a die using die,
 81        so `6` would become a constant 6, while  `d()` converts `int`s to a standard die with that many sides,
 82        so `6` would become a d6. Thus the right-side conversion of `@` would be ambiguous.
 83        """
 84        if not isinstance(other, icepool.die.base.BaseDie):
 85            raise TypeError(f'The @ operator will not automatically convert the right side of type {type(other).__qualname__} to a die.')
 86        return self.d(other)
 87    
 88    def if_else(self, true_die, false_die, *, ndim=None, denominator_method='lcm'):
 89        """ If the result of `self` has a true value, roll `true_die`, else roll `false_die`.
 90        
 91        Also known as the ternary conditional operator.
 92        
 93        Args:
 94            true_die: The die to roll if `self.bool()` rolls `True`.
 95            false_die: The die to roll if `self.bool()` rolls `False`.
 96            denominator_method: As `icepool.Die()`.
 97        """
 98        return self.sub(lambda outcome: true_die if bool(outcome) else false_die, ndim=ndim, denominator_method=denominator_method)
 99    
100    # Statistics.
101    
102    def median_left(self):
103        """ Returns the median.
104        
105        If the median lies between two outcomes, returns the lower of the two. """
106        return self.ppf_left(1, 2)
107    
108    def median_right(self):
109        """ Returns the median.
110        
111        If the median lies between two outcomes, returns the higher of the two. """
112        return self.ppf_right(1, 2)
113    
114    def median(self):
115        """ Returns the median.
116        
117        If the median lies between two outcomes, returns the mean of the two.
118        This will fail if the outcomes do not support division;
119        in this case, use `median_left` or `median_right` instead.
120        """
121        return self.ppf(1, 2)
122    
123    def ppf_left(self, n, d=100):
124        """ Returns a quantile, `n / d` of the way through the cdf.
125        
126        If the result lies between two outcomes, returns the lower of the two.
127        """
128        index = bisect.bisect_left(self.cweights(), (n * self.denominator() + d - 1) // d)
129        if index >= self.num_outcomes(): return self.max_outcome()
130        return self.outcomes()[index]
131    
132    def ppf_right(self, n, d=100):
133        """ Returns a quantile, `n / d` of the way through the cdf.
134        
135        If the result lies between two outcomes, returns the higher of the two.
136        """
137        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.cweights(), n * self.denominator() // d)
138        if index >= self.num_outcomes(): return self.max_outcome()
139        return self.outcomes()[index]
140    
141    def ppf(self, n, d=100):
142        """ Returns a quantile, `n / d` of the way through the cdf.
143        
144        If the result lies between two outcomes, returns the mean of the two.
145        This will fail if the outcomes do not support division;
146        in this case, use `ppf_left` or `ppf_right` instead.
147        """
148        return (self.ppf_left(n, d) + self.ppf_right(n, d)) / 2
149    
150    def mean(self):
151        return sum(outcome * p for outcome, p in zip(self.outcomes(), self.pmf()))
152    
153    def variance(self):
154        mean = self.mean()
155        mean_of_squares = sum(p * outcome ** 2 for outcome, p in zip(self.outcomes(), self.pmf()))
156        return mean_of_squares - mean * mean
157    
158    def standard_deviation(self):
159        return math.sqrt(self.variance())
160    
161    sd = standard_deviation
162    
163    def standardized_moment(self, k):
164        sd = self.standard_deviation()
165        mean = self.mean()
166        ev = sum(p * (outcome - mean) ** k for outcome, p in zip(self.outcomes(), self.pmf()))
167        return ev / (sd ** k)
168    
169    def skewness(self):
170        return self.standardized_moment(3.0)
171    
172    def excess_kurtosis(self):
173        return self.standardized_moment(4.0) - 3.0
174    
175    def cartesian_product(*dice):
176        """
177        Produces a `VectorDie` from the Cartesian product of the input `ScalarDie`.
178        
179        This is usually not recommended, as it takes space and time exponential in the number of dice,
180        while not actually producing any additional information.
181        
182        Args:
183            *dice: Multiple dice or a single iterable of dice.
184        
185        Raises:
186            `TypeError` if any of the input dice are already `VectorDie`.
187        """
188        if any(die.ndim > 1 for die in dice):
189            raise TypeError('cartesian_product() is only valid on ScalarDie.')
190        
191        data = defaultdict(int)
192        for t in itertools.product(*(die.items() for die in dice)):
193            outcomes, weights = zip(*t)
194            data[outcomes] += math.prod(weights)
195        
196        return icepool.Die(data, ndim=len(dice))
197    
198    def __repr__(self):
199        return type(self).__qualname__ + f'({self._data.__repr__()})'
200    
201    def markdown(self, include_weights=True):
202        outcome_length = max(tuple(len(str(outcome)) for outcome in self.outcomes()) + (len('Outcome'),))
203        result = ''
204        result += f'Denominator: {self.denominator()}\n\n'
205        result +=  '| ' + ' ' * (outcome_length - len('Outcome')) + 'Outcome |'
206        if include_weights:
207            weight_length = max(tuple(len(str(weight)) for weight in self.weights()) + (len('Weight'),))
208            result +=   ' ' + ' ' * (weight_length - len('Weight'))   +  'Weight |'
209        if self.denominator() > 0:
210            result += ' Probability |'
211        result += '\n'
212        result += '|-' + '-' * outcome_length + ':|'
213        if include_weights:
214            result += '-' + '-' * weight_length + ':|'
215        if self.denominator() > 0:
216            result += '------------:|'
217        result += '\n'
218        for outcome, weight, p in zip(self.outcomes(), self.weights(), self.pmf()):
219            result += f'| {str(outcome):>{outcome_length}} |'
220            if include_weights:
221                result += f' {weight:>{weight_length}} |'
222            if self.denominator() > 0:
223                result += f' {p:11.6%} |'
224            result += '\n'
225        return result

Univariate die.

Outcomes are scalars and operations are performed directly on the outcomes.

#   def d(self, other, *, ndim=None):
View Source 
52    def d(self, other, *, ndim=None):
53        """ Roll the left die, then roll the right die that many times and sum the outcomes. 
54        
55        If an `int` is provided for the right side, it becomes a standard die with that many faces.
56        Otherwise it is cast to a die.
57        """
58        if isinstance(other, int):
59            other = icepool.standard(other)
60        else:
61            other = icepool.Die(other, ndim=ndim)
62        
63        data = defaultdict(int)
64        
65        max_abs_die_count = max(abs(self.min_outcome()), abs(self.max_outcome()))
66        for die_count, die_count_weight in self.items():
67            factor = other.denominator() ** (max_abs_die_count - abs(die_count))
68            subresult = other.repeat_and_sum(die_count)
69            for outcome, subresult_weight in subresult.items():
70                data[outcome] += subresult_weight * die_count_weight * factor
71            
72        return icepool.Die(data, ndim=other.ndim())

Roll the left die, then roll the right die that many times and sum the outcomes.

If an int is provided for the right side, it becomes a standard die with that many faces. Otherwise it is cast to a die.

#   class VectorDie(icepool.BaseDie):
View Source 
 11class VectorDie(icepool.die.base.BaseDie):
 12    """ Multivariate die.
 13    
 14    Outcomes are tuples. Most methods and operators are performed elementwise.
 15    Methods that depend on a flat outcome order use tuple order.
 16    
 17    Statistical methods other than `mode()` take in an argument `i` specifying which dimension to take the statistic over.
 18    """
 19    
 20    def ndim(self):
 21        return self._ndim
 22    
 23    def __init__(self, data, ndim):
 24        """ Constructor.
 25        
 26        Dice should not be constructed directly;
 27        instead, use one of the methods defined in `icepool.die.func` 
 28        (which are imported into the top-level `icepool` module).
 29        
 30        Args:
 31            data: A `Counts` mapping outcomes to weights.
 32            ndim: The number of dimensions of this die.
 33        """
 34        self._data = data
 35        self._ndim = ndim
 36    
 37    def _unary_op(self, op, *args, **kwargs):
 38        """ Returns a die representing the effect of performing the operation elementwise on the outcome sequences. """
 39        data = defaultdict(int)
 40        for outcome, weight in self.items():
 41            new_outcome = tuple(op(x, *args, **kwargs) for x in outcome)
 42            data[new_outcome] += weight
 43        return icepool.Die(data, ndim=self.ndim())
 44    
 45    def _binary_op(self, other, op, *args, **kwargs):
 46        """ Returns a die representing the effect of performing the operation elementwise on pairs of outcome sequences from the two dice. """
 47        data = defaultdict(int)
 48        for (outcome_self, weight_self), (outcome_other, weight_other) in itertools.product(self.items(), other.items()):
 49            new_outcome = tuple(op(x, y, *args, **kwargs) for x, y in zip(outcome_self, outcome_other))
 50            data[new_outcome] += weight_self * weight_other
 51        return icepool.Die(data, ndim=self.ndim())
 52    
 53    def _wrap_unpack(self, func):
 54        @wraps(func)
 55        def unpacked_func(outcome):
 56            return func(*outcome)
 57        return unpacked_func
 58    
 59    def marginal(self, select):
 60        """ Returns the marginal distribution over selected dimensions of the die. """
 61        test_select = ([None] * self.ndim())[select]
 62        if hasattr(test_select, '__len__'):
 63            ndim = len(test_select)
 64        else:
 65            ndim = 'scalar'
 66        data = defaultdict(int)
 67        for outcome, weight in self.items():
 68            data[outcome[select]] += weight
 69        return icepool.Die(data, ndim=ndim)
 70    
 71    @cached_property
 72    def dim(self):
 73        """ Subscript this to produce a marginal distribution.
 74        
 75        For example, `die.dim[0]` will extract the 0th dimension.
 76        """
 77        return Slicer(self.marginal)
 78    
 79    def all(self):
 80        """ Returns a die representing whether all dimensions are true. """
 81        return self.sub(lambda *outcome: all(outcome), ndim='scalar')
 82    
 83    def any(self):
 84        """ Returns a die representing whether any dimension is true. """
 85        return self.sub(lambda *outcome: any(outcome), ndim='scalar')
 86    
 87    # Statistics.
 88    # These apply to a single dimension `i`.
 89    
 90    def _apply_to_dim(self, func, i, *args, **kwargs):
 91        return func(self[i], *args, **kwargs)
 92    
 93    def median_left(self, i):
 94        return self._apply_to_dim(icepool.ScalarDie.median_left, i)
 95        
 96    def median_right(self, i):
 97        return self._apply_to_dim(icepool.ScalarDie.median_right, i)
 98    
 99    def median(self, i):
100        return self._apply_to_dim(icepool.ScalarDie.median, i)
101    
102    def ppf_left(self, i):
103        return self._apply_to_dim(icepool.ScalarDie.ppf_left, i)
104        
105    def ppf_right(self, i):
106        return self._apply_to_dim(icepool.ScalarDie.ppf_right, i)
107    
108    def ppf(self, i):
109        return self._apply_to_dim(icepool.ScalarDie.ppf, i)
110        
111    def mean(self, i):
112        return self._apply_to_dim(icepool.ScalarDie.mean, i)
113    
114    def variance(self, i):
115        return self._apply_to_dim(icepool.ScalarDie.variance, i)
116    
117    def standard_deviation(self, i):
118        return self._apply_to_dim(icepool.ScalarDie.standard_deviation, i)
119    
120    sd = standard_deviation
121    
122    def standardized_moment(self, i, k):
123        return self._apply_to_dim(icepool.ScalarDie.standardized_moment, i, k)
124    
125    def skewness(self, i):
126        return self._apply_to_dim(icepool.ScalarDie.skewness, i)
127        
128    def excess_kurtosis(self, i):
129        return self._apply_to_dim(icepool.ScalarDie.excess_kurtosis, i)
130    
131    # Joint statistics.
132    
133    def covariance(self, i, j):
134        mean_i = self[i].mean()
135        mean_j = self[j].mean()
136        return sum((outcome[i] - mean_i) * (outcome[j] - mean_j) * weight for outcome, weight in self.items()) / self.denominator()
137    
138    def correlation(self, i, j):
139        sd_i = self[i].standard_deviation()
140        sd_j = self[j].standard_deviation()
141        return self.covariance(i, j) / (sd_i * sd_j)
142    
143    def __repr__(self):
144        return type(self).__qualname__ + f'({self._data.__repr__()}, ndim={self.ndim()})'
145    
146    def markdown(self, include_weights=True):
147        """ Formats the die as a Markdown table. """
148        outcome_lengths = []
149        for i in range(self.ndim()):
150            outcome_length = max(tuple(len(str(outcome[i])) for outcome in self.outcomes()) + (len(f'Outcome[{i}]'),))
151            outcome_lengths.append(outcome_length)
152        result = ''
153        result += f'Denominator: {self.denominator()}\n\n'
154        result += '|'
155        for i in range(self.ndim()):
156            result += ' ' + ' ' * (outcome_lengths[i] - len(f'Outcome[{i}]')) + f'Outcome[{i}]' + ' |'
157        if include_weights:
158            weight_length = max(tuple(len(str(weight)) for weight in self.weights()) + (len('Weight'),))
159            result += ' ' + ' ' * (weight_length - len('Weight')) + 'Weight |'
160        if self.denominator() > 0:
161            result += ' Probability |'
162        result += '\n'
163        result += '|'
164        for i in range(self.ndim()):
165            result += '-' + '-' * outcome_lengths[i] + ':|'
166        if include_weights:
167            result += '-' + '-' * weight_length + ':|'
168        if self.denominator() > 0:
169            result += '------------:|'
170        result += '\n'
171        for outcome, weight, p in zip(self.outcomes(), self.weights(), self.pmf()):
172            result += '|'
173            for i, x in enumerate(outcome):
174                result += f' {str(x):>{outcome_lengths[i]}} |'
175            if include_weights:
176                result += f' {weight:>{weight_length}} |'
177            if self.denominator() > 0:
178                result += f' {p:11.6%} |'
179            result += '\n'
180        return result

Multivariate die.

Outcomes are tuples. Most methods and operators are performed elementwise. Methods that depend on a flat outcome order use tuple order.

Statistical methods other than mode() take in an argument i specifying which dimension to take the statistic over.

#   def marginal(self, select):

59    def marginal(self, select):
60        """ Returns the marginal distribution over selected dimensions of the die. """
61        test_select = ([None] * self.ndim())[select]
62        if hasattr(test_select, '__len__'):
63            ndim = len(test_select)
64        else:
65            ndim = 'scalar'
66        data = defaultdict(int)
67        for outcome, weight in self.items():
68            data[outcome[select]] += weight
69        return icepool.Die(data, ndim=ndim)

#   def covariance(self, i, j):
View Source 
133    def covariance(self, i, j):
134        mean_i = self[i].mean()
135        mean_j = self[j].mean()
136        return sum((outcome[i] - mean_i) * (outcome[j] - mean_j) * weight for outcome, weight in self.items()) / self.denominator()
#   def correlation(self, i, j):
View Source 
138    def correlation(self, i, j):
139        sd_i = self[i].standard_deviation()
140        sd_j = self[j].standard_deviation()
141        return self.covariance(i, j) / (sd_i * sd_j)
#   def markdown(self, include_weights=True):
View Source 
146    def markdown(self, include_weights=True):
147        """ Formats the die as a Markdown table. """
148        outcome_lengths = []
149        for i in range(self.ndim()):
150            outcome_length = max(tuple(len(str(outcome[i])) for outcome in self.outcomes()) + (len(f'Outcome[{i}]'),))
151            outcome_lengths.append(outcome_length)
152        result = ''
153        result += f'Denominator: {self.denominator()}\n\n'
154        result += '|'
155        for i in range(self.ndim()):
156            result += ' ' + ' ' * (outcome_lengths[i] - len(f'Outcome[{i}]')) + f'Outcome[{i}]' + ' |'
157        if include_weights:
158            weight_length = max(tuple(len(str(weight)) for weight in self.weights()) + (len('Weight'),))
159            result += ' ' + ' ' * (weight_length - len('Weight')) + 'Weight |'
160        if self.denominator() > 0:
161            result += ' Probability |'
162        result += '\n'
163        result += '|'
164        for i in range(self.ndim()):
165            result += '-' + '-' * outcome_lengths[i] + ':|'
166        if include_weights:
167            result += '-' + '-' * weight_length + ':|'
168        if self.denominator() > 0:
169            result += '------------:|'
170        result += '\n'
171        for outcome, weight, p in zip(self.outcomes(), self.weights(), self.pmf()):
172            result += '|'
173            for i, x in enumerate(outcome):
174                result += f' {str(x):>{outcome_lengths[i]}} |'
175            if include_weights:
176                result += f' {weight:>{weight_length}} |'
177            if self.denominator() > 0:
178                result += f' {p:11.6%} |'
179            result += '\n'
180        return result

#   def from_cweights(outcomes, cweights, *, ndim=None):
View Source 
61def from_cweights(outcomes, cweights, *, ndim=None):
62    """ Constructs a die from cumulative weights. """
63    prev = 0
64    d = {}
65    for outcome, weight in zip(outcomes, cweights):
66        d[outcome] = weight - prev
67        prev = weight
68    return icepool.Die(d, ndim=ndim)

#   def from_sweights(outcomes, sweights, *, ndim=None):
View Source 
70def from_sweights(outcomes, sweights, *, ndim=None):
71    """ Constructs a die from survival weights. """
72    prev = 0
73    d = {}
74    for outcome, weight in zip(reversed(outcomes), reversed(tuple(sweights))):
75        d[outcome] = weight - prev
76        prev = weight
77    return icepool.Die(d, ndim=ndim)

#   def from_rv(rv, outcomes, denominator, **kwargs):
View Source 
79def from_rv(rv, outcomes, denominator, **kwargs):
80    """ Constructs a die from a rv object (as `scipy.stats`).
81    Args:
82        rv: A rv object (as `scipy.stats`).
83        outcomes: An iterable of `int`s or `float`s that will be the outcomes of the resulting die.
84            If the distribution is discrete, outcomes must be `int`s.
85        denominator: The denominator of the resulting die will be set to this.
86        **kwargs: These will be provided to `rv.cdf()`.
87    """
88    if hasattr(rv, 'pdf'):
89        # Continuous distributions use midpoints.
90        midpoints = [(a + b) / 2 for a, b in zip(outcomes[:-1], outcomes[1:])]
91        cdf = rv.cdf(midpoints, **kwargs)
92        cweights = tuple(int(round(x * denominator)) for x in cdf) + (denominator,)
93    else:
94        cdf = rv.cdf(outcomes, **kwargs)
95        cweights = tuple(int(round(x * denominator)) for x in cdf)
96    return from_cweights(outcomes, cweights)

Constructs a die from a rv object (as scipy.stats).

Args
  • rv: A rv object (as scipy.stats).
  • outcomes: An iterable of ints or floats that will be the outcomes of the resulting die. If the distribution is discrete, outcomes must be ints.
  • denominator: The denominator of the resulting die will be set to this.
  • **kwargs: These will be provided to rv.cdf().

 98def align(*dice, ndim=None):
 99    """Pads all the dice with zero weights so that all have the same set of outcomes.
100    
101    Args:
102        *dice: Multiple dice or a single iterable of dice.
103        ndim: The number of dimensions of the result.
104    
105    Returns:
106        A tuple of aligned dice.
107    
108    Raises:
109        `ValueError` if the dice are of mixed ndims.
110    """
111    dice, ndim = icepool.dice_with_common_ndim(*dice)
112    outcomes = set(itertools.chain.from_iterable(die.outcomes() for die in dice))
113    return tuple(die.set_outcomes(outcomes) for die in dice)

#   def lowest(*dice):
View Source 
529    def lowest(*dice):
530        """ Roll all the dice and take the lowest.
531        
532        The maximum outcome is equal to the highest maximum outcome among all input dice.
533        """
534        dice, ndim = icepool.dice_with_common_ndim(*dice)
535        max_outcome = min(die.max_outcome() for die in dice)
536        dice = [die.clip(max_outcome=max_outcome) for die in dice]
537        dice = icepool.align(*dice)
538        sweights = tuple(math.prod(t) for t in zip(*(die.sweights() for die in dice)))
539        return icepool.from_sweights(dice[0].outcomes(), sweights, ndim=ndim)

#   def apply(func, *dice, ndim=None):
View Source 
121def apply(func, *dice, ndim=None):
122    """ Applies `func(outcome_of_die_0, outcome_of_die_1, ...)` for all possible outcomes of the dice.
123    
124    This is flexible but not very efficient for large numbers of dice.
125    In particular, for pools use `icepool.Pool` and `icepool.EvalPool` instead if possible.
126    
127    Args:
128        func: A function that takes one argument per input die and returns an argument to `Die()`.
129        ndim: If supplied, the result will have this many dimensions.
130    
131    Returns:
132        A die constructed from the outputs of `func` and the product of the weights of the dice.
133    """
134    # No common ndim required for the inputs in this case.
135    dice = [icepool.Die(die) for die in dice]
136    final_outcomes = []
137    final_weights = []
138    data = defaultdict(int)
139    for t in itertools.product(*(die.items() for die in dice)):
140        outcomes, weights = zip(*t)
141        final_outcome = func(*outcomes)
142        final_weight = math.prod(weights)
143        if final_outcome is not icepool.Reroll:
144            final_outcomes.append(final_outcome)
145            final_weights.append(final_weight)
146    
147    return icepool.Die(*final_outcomes, weights=final_weights, ndim=ndim)

Applies func(outcome_of_die_0, outcome_of_die_1, ...) for all possible outcomes of the dice.

This is flexible but not very efficient for large numbers of dice. In particular, for pools use icepool.Pool and icepool.EvalPool instead if possible.

Args
  • func: A function that takes one argument per input die and returns an argument to Die().
  • ndim: If supplied, the result will have this many dimensions.
Returns

A die constructed from the outputs of func and the product of the weights of the dice.

#   class BasePool(abc.ABC):
View Source 
  7class BasePool(ABC):
  8    """ Abstract base class for dice pools.
  9    
 10    This provides the methods needed to run the dice pool algorithm.
 11    
 12    There are two subclasses:
 13    
 14    * `DicePool`, which represents a pool of dice with random results.
 15    * `PoolRoll`, which represents a single, fixed roll of a pool.
 16        `PoolRoll` is only needed internally, as external dicts and sequences 
 17        will be implicitly cast to `PoolRoll` in `EvalPool.eval()`.
 18    """
 19    
 20    @abstractmethod
 21    def _is_single_roll(self):
 22        """ Returns `True` iff this is a single, fixed roll of a pool. """
 23    
 24    @abstractmethod
 25    def _has_truncate_min(self):
 26        """ Returns `True` iff the pool has truncated min outcomes. """
 27    
 28    @abstractmethod
 29    def _has_truncate_max(self):
 30        """ Returns `True` iff the pool has truncated max outcomes. """
 31    
 32    @abstractmethod
 33    def outcomes(self):
 34        """ The outcomes of the fundamental die (including those with zero weight). """
 35    
 36    @abstractmethod
 37    def _min_outcome(self):
 38        """ The minimum outcome of the fundamental die. """
 39    
 40    @abstractmethod
 41    def _max_outcome(self):
 42        """ The maximum outcome of the fundamental die. """
 43        
 44    @abstractmethod
 45    def _direction_score_ascending(self):
 46        """ Returns a number indicating how preferred iterating in the ascending direction is.
 47        
 48        This is only called when there is no truncation.
 49        
 50        If the pool does not care at all about direction, the result is 0.
 51        
 52        The collective score is summed.
 53        """
 54    
 55    @abstractmethod
 56    def _direction_score_descending(self):
 57        """ Returns a number indicating how preferred iterating in the descending direction is.
 58        
 59        This is only called when there is no truncation.
 60        
 61        If the pool does not care at all about direction, the result is 0.
 62        
 63        The collective score is summed.
 64        """
 65    
 66    @abstractmethod
 67    def _pop_min(self):
 68        """ Returns a sequence of pool, count, weight corresponding to removing the min outcome,
 69        with count and weight corresponding to various numbers of dice rolling that outcome.
 70        """
 71    
 72    @abstractmethod
 73    def _pop_max(self):
 74        """ Returns a sequence of pool, count, weight corresponding to removing the max outcome,
 75        with count and weight corresponding to various numbers of dice rolling that outcome.
 76        """
 77    
 78    def eval(self, eval_or_func, /):
 79        """ Evaluates this pool using the given `EvalPool` or function.
 80        
 81        Note that each `EvalPool` instance carries its own cache;
 82        if you plan to use an evaluation multiple times,
 83        you may want to explicitly create an `EvalPool` instance
 84        rather than passing a function to this method directly.
 85        
 86        Args:
 87            func: This can be an `EvalPool`, in which case it evaluates the pool directly.
 88                Or it can be a `EvalPool.next_state()`-like function,
 89                taking in `state, outcome, *counts` and returning the next state.
 90                In this case a temporary `WrapFuncEval` is constructed and used to evaluate this pool.
 91        """
 92        if not isinstance(eval_or_func, icepool.EvalPool):
 93            eval_or_func = icepool.WrapFuncEval(eval_or_func)
 94        return eval_or_func.eval(self)
 95
 96    def sum(self):
 97        """ Convenience method to simply sum the dice in this pool.
 98        
 99        This uses `icepool.sum_pool`.
100        
101        Returns:
102            A die representing the sum.
103        """
104        return icepool.sum_pool(self)

Abstract base class for dice pools.

This provides the methods needed to run the dice pool algorithm.

There are two subclasses:

  • DicePool, which represents a pool of dice with random results.
  • PoolRoll, which represents a single, fixed roll of a pool. PoolRoll is only needed internally, as external dicts and sequences will be implicitly cast to PoolRoll in EvalPool.eval().

80        
81        Note that each `EvalPool` instance carries its own cache;
82        if you plan to use an evaluation multiple times,
83        you may want to explicitly create an `EvalPool` instance
84        rather than passing a function to this method directly.
85        
86        Args:
87            func: This can be an `EvalPool`, in which case it evaluates the pool directly.
88                Or it can be a `EvalPool.next_state()`-like function,
89                taking in `state, outcome, *counts` and returning the next state.
90                In this case a temporary `WrapFuncEval` is constructed and used to evaluate this pool.
91        """

93            eval_or_func = icepool.WrapFuncEval(eval_or_func)
94        return eval_or_func.eval(self)

#   def Pool( die, num_dice=None, count_dice=None, *, truncate_min=None, truncate_max=None ):
View Source 
 11def Pool(die, num_dice=None, count_dice=None, *, truncate_min=None, truncate_max=None):
 12    """ Factory function for `DicePool`.
 13    
 14    This should be used in conjunction with `EvalPool` to generate a result.
 15    
 16    You can use `die.pool(num_dice=None, ...)` for the same effect as this function.
 17    
 18    All instances are cached. The members of the actual instance may not match the arguments exactly;
 19    instead, they may be optimized to values that give the same result as far as `EvalPool` is concerned.
 20    
 21    This is capitalized because it is the preferred way of getting a new instance,
 22    and so that you can use `from icepool import Pool` while leaving the name `pool` free.
 23    The name of the actual class is `DicePool`.
 24    
 25    Args:
 26        die: The fundamental die of the pool.
 27            If outcomes are not reachable by any die due to `truncate_min` or `truncate_max`,
 28            they will have 0 count. Zero-weight outcomes will appear with zero weight,
 29            but can still generate nonzero counts.
 30        num_dice: An `int` that sets the number of dice in the pool.
 31            If not provided, the number of dice will be inferred from the other arguments.
 32            If no arguments are provided at all, this defaults to 0.
 33        count_dice: Determines which of the **sorted** dice will be counted, and how many times.
 34            Prefer to use the `DicePool`'s `[]` operator after the fact rather than providing an argument here.
 35            This operator is an alias for `DicePool.set_count_dice()`.
 36            See that method's docstring for details.
 37        truncate_max: A sequence of one outcome per die in the pool.
 38            That die will be truncated to that maximum outcome, with all greater outcomes having 0 count.
 39            Values cannot be > the `max_outcome` of the fundamental die.
 40            A pool cannot have both `truncate_min` and `truncate_max`.
 41            This can be used to efficiently roll a set of mixed standard dice.
 42            For example, `Pool(icepool.d12, truncate_max=[6, 6, 6, 8, 8])` would be a pool of 3d6 and 2d8.
 43        truncate_min: A sequence of one outcome per die in the pool.
 44            That die will be truncated to that minimum outcome, with all lesser outcomes having 0 count.
 45            Values cannot be < the `min_outcome` of the fundamental die.
 46            A pool cannot have both `truncate_min` and `truncate_max`.
 47    
 48    Raises:
 49        `ValueError` if arguments result in a conflicting number of dice,
 50        if both `truncate_min` and `truncate_max` are provided,
 51        or if truncation would produce an empty die.
 52    """
 53    
 54    if truncate_min is not None and truncate_max is not None:
 55        raise ValueError('A pool cannot have both truncate_min and truncate_max.')
 56    
 57    # Compute num_dice and count_dice.
 58    
 59    for seq in (truncate_min, truncate_max):
 60        if hasattr(seq, '__len__'):
 61            if num_dice is not None and num_dice != len(seq):
 62                raise ValueError('Conflicting values for the number of dice: ' +
 63                    f'num_dice={num_dice}, truncate_min={truncate_min}, truncate_max={truncate_max}')
 64            else:
 65                num_dice = len(seq)
 66    
 67    convert_to_die = isinstance(count_dice, int)
 68    
 69    if num_dice is None:
 70        # Default to zero dice, unless count_dice has something to say.
 71        count_dice = count_dice_tuple(0, count_dice)
 72        num_dice = len(count_dice)
 73    else:
 74        # Must match num_dice.
 75        count_dice = count_dice_tuple(num_dice, count_dice)
 76        if len(count_dice) != num_dice:
 77            raise ValueError(f'The length of count_dice={count_dice} conflicts with num_dice={num_dice}.')
 78    
 79    # Put truncation into standard form.
 80    # This is either a sorted tuple, or `None` if there is no (effective) limit to the die size on that side.
 81    # Values will also be clipped to the range of the fundamental die.
 82    
 83    if num_dice == 0:
 84        truncate_min = None
 85        truncate_max = None
 86    else:
 87        if truncate_min is not None:
 88            if max(truncate_min) > die.min_outcome():
 89                if min(truncate_min) < die.min_outcome():
 90                    raise ValueError('truncate_min cannot be < the min_outcome of the die.')
 91                # We can't truncate the die to truncate_min since it may upset the iteration order.
 92                truncate_min = tuple(sorted(die.nearest_ge(outcome) for outcome in truncate_min))
 93            else:
 94                # In this case, the truncate_min don't actually do anything.
 95                truncate_min = None
 96        if truncate_max is not None:
 97            if min(truncate_max) < die.max_outcome():
 98                if max(truncate_max) > die.max_outcome():
 99                    raise ValueError('truncate_max cannot be > the max_outcome of the die.')
100                # We can't truncate the die to truncate_max since it may upset the iteration order.
101                truncate_max = tuple(sorted(die.nearest_le(outcome) for outcome in truncate_max))
102            else:
103                # In this case, the truncate_max don't actually do anything.
104                truncate_max = None
105    
106    result = _pool_cached_unchecked(die, count_dice, truncate_min, truncate_max)
107    if convert_to_die:
108        return result.eval(lambda state, outcome, count: outcome if count else state)
109    else:
110        return result

Factory function for DicePool.

This should be used in conjunction with EvalPool to generate a result.

You can use die.pool(num_dice=None, ...) for the same effect as this function.

All instances are cached. The members of the actual instance may not match the arguments exactly; instead, they may be optimized to values that give the same result as far as EvalPool is concerned.

This is capitalized because it is the preferred way of getting a new instance, and so that you can use from icepool import Pool while leaving the name pool free. The name of the actual class is DicePool.

Args
  • die: The fundamental die of the pool. If outcomes are not reachable by any die due to truncate_min or truncate_max, they will have 0 count. Zero-weight outcomes will appear with zero weight, but can still generate nonzero counts.
  • num_dice: An int that sets the number of dice in the pool. If not provided, the number of dice will be inferred from the other arguments. If no arguments are provided at all, this defaults to 0.
  • count_dice: Determines which of the sorted dice will be counted, and how many times. Prefer to use the DicePool's [] operator after the fact rather than providing an argument here. This operator is an alias for DicePool.set_count_dice(). See that method's docstring for details.
  • truncate_max: A sequence of one outcome per die in the pool. That die will be truncated to that maximum outcome, with all greater outcomes having 0 count. Values cannot be > the max_outcome of the fundamental die. A pool cannot have both truncate_min and truncate_max. This can be used to efficiently roll a set of mixed standard dice. For example, Pool(icepool.d12, truncate_max=[6, 6, 6, 8, 8]) would be a pool of 3d6 and 2d8.
  • truncate_min: A sequence of one outcome per die in the pool. That die will be truncated to that minimum outcome, with all lesser outcomes having 0 count. Values cannot be < the min_outcome of the fundamental die. A pool cannot have both truncate_min and truncate_max.
Raises
  • ValueError if arguments result in a conflicting number of dice,
  • if both truncate_min and truncate_max are provided,
  • or if truncation would produce an empty die.
#   def standard_pool(*die_sizes, count_dice=None):
View Source 
195def standard_pool(*die_sizes, count_dice=None):
196    """ Creates a pool of standard dice.
197    
198    For example, `standard_pool(8, 8, 6, 6, 6)` would be a pool of 2 d8s and 3 d6s.
199    
200    If no die sizes are given, the pool will consist of zero d1s.
201    
202    Args:
203        *die_sizes: The size of each die in the pool.
204        count_dice: Which dice will be counted, as `Pool()`.
205            As with `Pool()`, you can also use the `[]` operator after the fact.
206            For example, `standard_pool(8, 8, 6, 6, 6)[-2:]` would keep the highest two dice
207            of 2 d8s and 3 d6s.
208    """
209    if len(die_sizes) == 0:
210        return Pool(icepool.d1, num_dice=0)
211    return Pool(icepool.d(max(die_sizes)), count_dice=count_dice, truncate_max=die_sizes)

Creates a pool of standard dice.

For example, standard_pool(8, 8, 6, 6, 6) would be a pool of 2 d8s and 3 d6s.

If no die sizes are given, the pool will consist of zero d1s.

Args
  • *die_sizes: The size of each die in the pool.
  • count_dice: Which dice will be counted, as Pool(). As with Pool(), you can also use the [] operator after the fact. For example, standard_pool(8, 8, 6, 6, 6)[-2:] would keep the highest two dice of 2 d8s and 3 d6s.
#   class DicePool(icepool.BasePool):
View Source 
213class DicePool(icepool.BasePool):
214    """ A pool is a set of (semi-)identical dice that are rolled in no particular order
215    and sorted only after the fact.
216    
217    A pool is defined by:
218
219    * A fundamental die.
220    * The number of dice in the pool.
221    * Which of the sorted positions are counted (possibly multiple or negative times).
222    * Possibly limiting the max or min outcomes of dice in the pool (but not both)
223        relative to the fundamental die.
224    """
225    
226    def __init__(self, die, count_dice, *, truncate_min, truncate_max):
227        """ Unchecked constructor.
228        
229        This should not be used directly. Use the `Pool()` factory function instead.
230        
231        Args:
232            die: The fundamental die of the pool.
233            count_dice: At this point, this should be a tuple the length of the pool.
234            truncate_max: At this point this should be a tuple the length of the pool or `None`.
235            truncate_min: At this point this should be a tuple the length of the pool or `None`.
236        """
237        self._die = die
238        self._count_dice = count_dice
239        self._truncate_max = truncate_max
240        self._truncate_min = truncate_min
241    
242    def _is_single_roll(self):
243        return False
244    
245    def die(self):
246        """ The fundamental die of the pool. """
247        return self._die
248    
249    def outcomes(self):
250        return self.die().outcomes()
251        
252    def _min_outcome(self):
253        return self.die().min_outcome()
254    
255    def _max_outcome(self):
256        return self.die().max_outcome()
257        
258    def count_dice(self):
259        """ A tuple indicating how many times each of the dice, sorted from lowest to highest, counts. """
260        return self._count_dice
261    
262    def num_dice(self):
263        """ The number of dice in this pool (before dropping or counting multiple times). """
264        return len(self._count_dice)
265    
266    def set_count_dice(self, count_dice):
267        """ Returns a pool with the selected dice counted.
268        
269        You can use `pool[count_dice]` for the same effect as this method.
270        
271        The dice are sorted in ascending order for this purpose,
272        regardless of which order the outcomes are evaluated in.
273        
274        This is always an absolute selection on all `num_dice`,
275        not a relative selection on already-selected dice,
276        which would be ambiguous in the presence of multiple or negative counts.
277        
278        Args:
279            `None`: All dice will be counted once.
280            An `int`. This will count only the die at the specified index (once).
281                In this case, the result will be a die, not a pool.
282            A `slice`. The selected dice are counted once each.
283                If provided, the third argument resizes the pool,
284                rather than being a step,
285                but only if the pool does not have `truncate_max` or `truncate_min`.
286            A sequence of one `int`s for each die.
287                Each die is counted that many times, which could be multiple or negative times.
288                This may resize the pool, but only if the pool does not have `truncate_max` or `truncate_min`.
289                
290                Up to one `Ellipsis` (`...`) may be used.
291                If an `Ellipsis` is used, the size of the pool won't change. Instead:
292                
293                * If `count_dice` is shorter than `num_dice`, the `Ellipsis`
294                    acts as enough zero counts to make up the difference.
295                    For example, `pool[1, ..., 1]` on five dice would act as `pool[1, 0, 0, 0, 1]`.
296                * If `count_dice` has length equal to `num_dice`, the `Ellipsis` has no effect.
297                    For example, `pool[1, ..., 1]` on two dice would act as `pool[1, 1]`.
298                * If `count_dice` is longer than `num_dice` and the `Ellipsis` is on one side,
299                    elements will be dropped from `count_dice` on the side with the `Ellipsis`.
300                    For example, `pool[..., 1, 2, 3]` on two dice would act as `pool[2, 3]`.
301                * If `count_dice` is longer than `num_dice` and the `Ellipsis` is in the middle,
302                    the counts will be as the sum of two one-sided `Ellipsis`.
303                    For example, `pool[-1, ..., 1]` acts like `[-1, ...]` plus `[..., 1]`.
304                    On a pool consisting of a single single die this would have the -1 and 1 cancel each other out.
305        
306        Raises:
307            ValueError:
308            
309                * If `count_dice` would change the size of a pool with `truncate_max` or `truncate_min`.
310                * If more than one `Ellipsis` is used.
311        
312        For example, here are some ways of selecting the two highest dice out of 5:
313        
314        * `pool[3:5]`
315        * `pool[3:]`
316        * `pool[-2:]`
317        * `pool[..., 1, 1]`
318        
319        These will also select the two highest dice out of 5, and will also resize the pool to 5 dice first:
320        
321        * `pool[3::5]`
322        * `pool[3:5:5]`
323        * `pool[-2::5]`
324        * `pool[0, 0, 0, 1, 1]`
325        
326        These will count the highest as a positive and the lowest as a negative:
327        
328        * `pool[-1, 0, 0, 0, 1]`
329        * `pool[-1, ..., 1]`
330        """
331        convert_to_die = isinstance(count_dice, int)
332        count_dice = count_dice_tuple(self.num_dice(), count_dice)
333        if len(count_dice) != self.num_dice():
334            if self.truncate_max() is not None:
335                raise ValueError('Cannot change the size of a pool with truncate_max.')
336            if self.truncate_min() is not None:
337                raise ValueError('Cannot change the size of a pool with truncate_min.')
338        result = _pool_cached_unchecked(self.die(), count_dice=count_dice, truncate_max=self.truncate_max(), truncate_min=self.truncate_min())
339        if convert_to_die:
340            return result.eval(lambda state, outcome, count: outcome if count else state)
341        else:
342            return result
343    
344    __getitem__ = set_count_dice
345    
346    def __iter__(self):
347        raise TypeError("'DicePool' object is not iterable")
348    
349    @cached_property
350    def _num_drop_lowest(self):
351        """ How many elements of count_dice on the low side are falsy. """
352        for i, count in enumerate(self.count_dice()):
353            if count:
354                return i
355        return self.num_dice()
356    
357    def _direction_score_ascending(self):
358        return self._num_drop_lowest * len(self.outcomes())
359    
360    @cached_property
361    def _num_drop_highest(self):
362        """ How many elements of count_dice on the high side are falsy. """
363        for i, count in enumerate(reversed(self.count_dice())):
364            if count:
365                return i
366        return self.num_dice()
367    
368    def _direction_score_descending(self):
369        return self._num_drop_highest * len(self.outcomes())
370    
371    def truncate_min(self, always_tuple=False):
372        """ A sorted tuple of thresholds below which outcomes are truncated, one for each die in the pool. 
373        
374        Args:
375            always_tuple: If `False`, this will return `None` if there are no die-specific `truncate_min`.
376                If `True` this will return a `tuple` even in this case.
377        """
378        if self._truncate_min is None and always_tuple:
379            return (self.die().min_outcome(),) * self.num_dice()
380        return self._truncate_min
381    
382    def _has_truncate_min(self):
383        return self._truncate_min is not None
384    
385    def truncate_max(self, always_tuple=False):
386        """ A sorted tuple of thresholds above which outcomes are truncated, one for each die in the pool. 
387        
388        Args:
389            always_tuple: If `False`, this will return `None` if there are no die-specific `truncate_max`.
390                If `True` this will return a `tuple` even in this case.
391        """
392        if self._truncate_max is None and always_tuple:
393            return (self.die().max_outcome(),) * self.num_dice()
394        return self._truncate_max
395    
396    def _has_truncate_max(self):
397        return self._truncate_max is not None
398    
399    def _iter_pop_min(self):
400        """
401        Yields:
402            From 0 to the number of dice that can roll this outcome inclusive:
403            * pool: A `DicePool` resulting from removing that many dice from this `DicePool`, while also removing the min outcome.
404                If there is only one outcome with weight remaining, only one result will be yielded, corresponding to all dice rolling that outcome.
405                If the outcome has zero weight, only one result will be yielded, corresponding to zero dice rolling that outcome.
406                If there are no outcomes remaining, this will be `None`.
407            * count: An `int` indicating the number of selected dice that rolled the removed outcome.
408            * weight: An `int` indicating the weight of that many dice rolling the removed outcome.
409        """
410        
411        # The near-duplication of code with pop_max is unfortunate.
412        # However, the alternative of reversing the storage order of die_counts and truncate_min seems even worse.
413        
414        truncate_min = self.truncate_min(always_tuple=True)
415        num_possible_dice = bisect.bisect_right(truncate_min, self.die().min_outcome())
416        popped_die, outcome, single_weight = self.die()._pop_min()
417        
418        if popped_die.is_empty():
419            # This is the last outcome. All dice must roll this outcome.
420            pool = _pool_cached_unchecked(popped_die, count_dice=())
421            remaining_count = sum(self.count_dice())
422            weight = single_weight ** num_possible_dice
423            yield pool, remaining_count, weight
424            return
425        
426        # Consider various numbers of dice rolling this outcome.
427        popped_truncate_min = (popped_die.min_outcome(),) * num_possible_dice + truncate_min[num_possible_dice:]
428        popped_count_dice = self.count_dice()
429        count = 0
430        
431        comb_row = icepool.math.comb_row(num_possible_dice, single_weight)
432        end_counted = self.num_dice() - self._num_drop_highest
433        for weight in comb_row[:min(num_possible_dice, end_counted)]:
434            pool = _pool_cached_unchecked(popped_die, count_dice=popped_count_dice, truncate_min=popped_truncate_min)
435            yield pool, count, weight
436            count += popped_count_dice[0]
437            popped_truncate_min = popped_truncate_min[1:]
438            popped_count_dice = popped_count_dice[1:]
439        
440        if end_counted > num_possible_dice:
441            pool = _pool_cached_unchecked(popped_die, count_dice=popped_count_dice, truncate_min=popped_truncate_min)
442            yield pool, count, comb_row[-1]
443        else:
444            # In this case, we ran out of counted dice before running out of dice that could roll the outcome.
445            # We empty the rest of the pool immediately since no more dice can contribute counts.
446            skip_weight = 0
447            for weight in comb_row[end_counted:]:
448                skip_weight *= popped_die.denominator()
449                skip_weight += weight
450            skip_weight *= math.prod(popped_die.weight_ge(min_outcome) for min_outcome in truncate_min[num_possible_dice:])
451            pool = _pool_cached_unchecked(popped_die, count_dice=())
452            yield pool, count, skip_weight
453    
454    def _iter_pop_max(self):
455        """
456        Yields:
457            From 0 to the number of dice that can roll this outcome inclusive:
458            * pool: A `DicePool` resulting from removing that many dice from this `DicePool`, while also removing the max outcome.
459                If there is only one outcome with weight remaining, only one result will be yielded, corresponding to all dice rolling that outcome.
460                If the outcome has zero weight, only one result will be yielded, corresponding to zero dice rolling that outcome.
461                If there are no outcomes remaining, this will be `None`.
462            * count: An `int` indicating the number of selected dice that rolled the removed outcome.
463            * weight: An `int` indicating the weight of that many dice rolling the removed outcome.
464        """
465        truncate_max = self.truncate_max(always_tuple=True)
466        num_possible_dice = self.num_dice() - bisect.bisect_left(truncate_max, self.die().max_outcome())
467        num_unused_dice = self.num_dice() - num_possible_dice
468        popped_die, outcome, single_weight = self.die()._pop_max()
469        
470        if popped_die.is_empty():
471            # This is the last outcome. All dice must roll this outcome.
472            pool = _pool_cached_unchecked(popped_die, count_dice=())
473            remaining_count = sum(self.count_dice())
474            weight = single_weight ** num_possible_dice
475            yield pool, remaining_count, weight
476            return
477        
478        # Consider various numbers of dice rolling this outcome.
479        popped_truncate_max = truncate_max[:num_unused_dice] + (popped_die.max_outcome(),) * num_possible_dice
480        popped_count_dice = self.count_dice()
481        count = 0
482        
483        comb_row = icepool.math.comb_row(num_possible_dice, single_weight)
484        end_counted = self.num_dice() - self._num_drop_lowest
485        for weight in comb_row[:min(num_possible_dice, end_counted)]:
486            pool = _pool_cached_unchecked(popped_die, count_dice=popped_count_dice, truncate_max=popped_truncate_max)
487            yield pool, count, weight
488            count += popped_count_dice[-1]
489            popped_truncate_max = popped_truncate_max[:-1]
490            popped_count_dice = popped_count_dice[:-1]
491        
492        if end_counted > num_possible_dice:
493            pool = _pool_cached_unchecked(popped_die, count_dice=popped_count_dice, truncate_max=popped_truncate_max)
494            yield pool, count, comb_row[-1]
495        else:
496            # In this case, we ran out of counted dice before running out of dice that could roll the outcome.
497            # We empty the rest of the pool immediately since no more dice can contribute counts.
498            skip_weight = 0
499            for weight in comb_row[end_counted:]:
500                skip_weight *= popped_die.denominator()
501                skip_weight += weight
502            skip_weight *= math.prod(popped_die.weight_le(max_outcome) for max_outcome in truncate_max[:num_unused_dice])
503            pool = _pool_cached_unchecked(popped_die, count_dice=())
504            yield pool, count, skip_weight
505    
506    @cached_property
507    def _popped_min(self):
508        if self.truncate_max() is not None:
509            raise ValueError('pop_min is not valid with truncate_min.')
510        return tuple(self._iter_pop_min())
511    
512    def _pop_min(self):
513        """ Returns a sequence of pool, count, weight corresponding to removing the min outcome,
514        with count and weight corresponding to various numbers of dice rolling that outcome.
515        """
516        return self._popped_min
517        
518    @cached_property
519    def _popped_max(self):
520        if self.truncate_min() is not None:
521            raise ValueError('pop_max is not valid with truncate_min.')
522        return tuple(self._iter_pop_max())
523    
524    def _pop_max(self):
525        """ Returns a sequence of pool, count, weight corresponding to removing the max outcome,
526        with count and weight corresponding to various numbers of dice rolling that outcome.
527        """
528        return self._popped_max
529        
530    def has_counted_dice(self):
531        """ Returns `True` iff any of the remaining dice are counted a nonzero number of times.
532        
533        This is used to skip to the base case when there are no more dice to consider.
534        """
535        return any(self.count_dice())
536    
537    def sample(self):
538        """ Samples a roll from this pool.
539        
540        Returns:
541            A dict mapping outcomes to counts representing a single roll of this pool.
542        """
543        raw_rolls = []
544        for min_outcome, max_outcome in zip(self.truncate_min(True), self.truncate_max(True)):
545            die = self.die().truncate(min_outcome, max_outcome)
546            raw_rolls.append(die.sample())
547        raw_rolls = sorted(raw_rolls)
548        data = defaultdict(int)
549        for roll, count in zip(raw_rolls, self.count_dice()):
550            data[roll] += count
551        return data
552    
553    @cached_property
554    def _key_tuple(self):
555        return self.die().key_tuple(), self.count_dice(), self.truncate_min(), self.truncate_max()
556    
557    def __eq__(self, other):
558        if not isinstance(other, DicePool): return False
559        return self._key_tuple == other._key_tuple
560    
561    @cached_property
562    def _hash(self):
563        return hash(self._key_tuple)
564        
565    def __hash__(self):
566        return self._hash
567
568    def __str__(self):
569        return '\n'.join([str(self.die()), str(self.count_dice()), str(self.truncate_min()), str(self.truncate_max())])

266    def set_count_dice(self, count_dice):
267        """ Returns a pool with the selected dice counted.
268        
269        You can use `pool[count_dice]` for the same effect as this method.
270        
271        The dice are sorted in ascending order for this purpose,
272        regardless of which order the outcomes are evaluated in.
273

276        which would be ambiguous in the presence of multiple or negative counts.
277        
278        Args:
279            `None`: All dice will be counted once.
280            An `int`. This will count only the die at the specified index (once).
281                In this case, the result will be a die, not a pool.
282            A `slice`. The selected dice are counted once each.
283                If provided, the third argument resizes the pool,
284                rather than being a step,
285                but only if the pool does not have `truncate_max` or `truncate_min`.
286            A sequence of one `int`s for each die.
287                Each die is counted that many times, which could be multiple or negative times.
288                This may resize the pool, but only if the pool does not have `truncate_max` or `truncate_min`.
289                
290                Up to one `Ellipsis` (`...`) may be used.
291                If an `Ellipsis` is used, the size of the pool won't change. Instead:
292                
293                * If `count_dice` is shorter than `num_dice`, the `Ellipsis`
294                    acts as enough zero counts to make up the difference.
295                    For example, `pool[1, ..., 1]` on five dice would act as `pool[1, 0, 0, 0, 1]`.
296                * If `count_dice` has length equal to `num_dice`, the `Ellipsis` has no effect.
297                    For example, `pool[1, ..., 1]` on two dice would act as `pool[1, 1]`.
298                * If `count_dice` is longer than `num_dice` and the `Ellipsis` is on one side,
299                    elements will be dropped from `count_dice` on the side with the `Ellipsis`.
300                    For example, `pool[..., 1, 2, 3]` on two dice would act as `pool[2, 3]`.
301                * If `count_dice` is longer than `num_dice` and the `Ellipsis` is in the middle,
302                    the counts will be as the sum of two one-sided `Ellipsis`.
303                    For example, `pool[-1, ..., 1]` acts like `[-1, ...]` plus `[..., 1]`.
304                    On a pool consisting of a single single die this would have the -1 and 1 cancel each other out.
305        
306        Raises:
307            ValueError:
308            
309                * If `count_dice` would change the size of a pool with `truncate_max` or `truncate_min`.
310                * If more than one `Ellipsis` is used.
311        
312        For example, here are some ways of selecting the two highest dice out of 5:
313        
314        * `pool[3:5]`
315        * `pool[3:]`
316        * `pool[-2:]`
317        * `pool[..., 1, 1]`
318        
319        These will also select the two highest dice out of 5, and will also resize the pool to 5 dice first:
320        
321        * `pool[3::5]`
322        * `pool[3:5:5]`
323        * `pool[-2::5]`
324        * `pool[0, 0, 0, 1, 1]`
325        
326        These will count the highest as a positive and the lowest as a negative:
327        
328        * `pool[-1, 0, 0, 0, 1]`
329        * `pool[-1, ..., 1]`
330        """
331        convert_to_die = isinstance(count_dice, int)
332        count_dice = count_dice_tuple(self.num_dice(), count_dice)
333        if len(count_dice) != self.num_dice():
334            if self.truncate_max() is not None:
335                raise ValueError('Cannot change the size of a pool with truncate_max.')
336            if self.truncate_min() is not None:
337                raise ValueError('Cannot change the size of a pool with truncate_min.')
338        result = _pool_cached_unchecked(self.die(), count_dice=count_dice, truncate_max=self.truncate_max(), truncate_min=self.truncate_min())
339        if convert_to_die:
340            return result.eval(lambda state, outcome, count: outcome if count else state)
341        else:
342            return result

Returns a pool with the selected dice counted.

You can use pool[count_dice] for the same effect as this method.

The dice are sorted in ascending order for this purpose, regardless of which order the outcomes are evaluated in.

This is always an absolute selection on all num_dice, not a relative selection on already-selected dice, which would be ambiguous in the presence of multiple or negative counts.

Args
  • None: All dice will be counted once.
  • An int. This will count only the die at the specified index (once). In this case, the result will be a die, not a pool.
  • A slice. The selected dice are counted once each. If provided, the third argument resizes the pool, rather than being a step, but only if the pool does not have truncate_max or truncate_min.

  • A sequence of one ints for each die. Each die is counted that many times, which could be multiple or negative times. This may resize the pool, but only if the pool does not have truncate_max or truncate_min.

    Up to one Ellipsis (...) may be used. If an Ellipsis is used, the size of the pool won't change. Instead:

    • If count_dice is shorter than num_dice, the Ellipsis acts as enough zero counts to make up the difference. For example, pool[1, ..., 1] on five dice would act as pool[1, 0, 0, 0, 1].
    • If count_dice has length equal to num_dice, the Ellipsis has no effect. For example, pool[1, ..., 1] on two dice would act as pool[1, 1].
    • If count_dice is longer than num_dice and the Ellipsis is on one side, elements will be dropped from count_dice on the side with the Ellipsis. For example, pool[..., 1, 2, 3] on two dice would act as pool[2, 3].
    • If count_dice is longer than num_dice and the Ellipsis is in the middle, the counts will be as the sum of two one-sided Ellipsis. For example, pool[-1, ..., 1] acts like [-1, ...] plus [..., 1]. On a pool consisting of a single single die this would have the -1 and 1 cancel each other out.
Raises
  • ValueError: * If count_dice would change the size of a pool with truncate_max or truncate_min.
    • If more than one Ellipsis is used.

For example, here are some ways of selecting the two highest dice out of 5:

  • pool[3:5]
  • pool[3:]
  • pool[-2:]
  • pool[..., 1, 1]

These will also select the two highest dice out of 5, and will also resize the pool to 5 dice first:

  • pool[3::5]
  • pool[3:5:5]
  • pool[-2::5]
  • pool[0, 0, 0, 1, 1]

These will count the highest as a positive and the lowest as a negative:

  • pool[-1, 0, 0, 0, 1]
  • pool[-1, ..., 1]

#   def sample(self):
View Source 
537    def sample(self):
538        """ Samples a roll from this pool.
539        
540        Returns:
541            A dict mapping outcomes to counts representing a single roll of this pool.
542        """
543        raw_rolls = []
544        for min_outcome, max_outcome in zip(self.truncate_min(True), self.truncate_max(True)):
545            die = self.die().truncate(min_outcome, max_outcome)
546            raw_rolls.append(die.sample())
547        raw_rolls = sorted(raw_rolls)
548        data = defaultdict(int)
549        for roll, count in zip(raw_rolls, self.count_dice()):
550            data[roll] += count
551        return data

#   class EvalPool(abc.ABC):
